pageData.text: As the principal organ of the nervous system, the brain regulates many processes needed to maintain the dynamic internal balance of <button class='glossary-text'>homeostasis</button>. In this activity, the student will be guided through the dissection and close examination of an adult mammalian brain. Although there are some differences between the specimen provided and a human brain, the structures and their relative locations are highly similar.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 10 minutes,
Activity 1: Brain Dissection - 45 minutes
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 10 minutes
Activity 1: Brain Dissection - 45 minutes

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Paper towels
70% isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) or other non-bleach disinfectant
Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking photos
Opaque trash bag

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Anatomy of the Brain

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Describe the composition and function of nervous tissue; differentiate between gray and white    matter.
Describe how the <button class='glossary-text'>central nervous system</button> is protected from injury, and identify the structures involved.
Apply anatomical terminology while examining and performing a longitudinal (lengthwise) dissection of an adult mammalian brain.
Identify the major regions of the brain, and associate them with their functions.
Identify key surface and internal features of each region of the brain.
Identify the <button class='glossary-text'>cranial nerves</button>, their composition, and their functions.

pageData.text: Every year new discoveries are made about how the brain and the rest of the body communicate. Some researchers are uncovering the complex interactions between the stomach, stomach microbes, and the brain. Other researchers are diving into how infants learn to communicate.And some researchers are creating robotic limbs that can not only restore movement, but also restore the sensation of touch for paralyzed or amputee patients. Skin can detect many different sensations, such as pressure or temperature; it rapidly sends this information to the brain, allowing us to perform many different tasks. The complex interaction between skin, muscle, and brain cells makes it difficult to restore sensation and movement in patients. But now, researchers are developing robotic limbs that can restore lost sensation. The robot contains contact sensors, and electrodes are placed in the patient’s skin just above the amputation site. The contact sensors are mapped with a computer algorithm to the electrodes, allowing the patient to sense the task the robot limb is performing. The results of the first trials seem extremely promising and it has been reported that when one patient touched an object with his robot figure, he had the sensation of brushing that object1.

Reference1George, J. A., Kluger, D. T., Davis, T. S., Wendelken, S. M., Okorokova, E. V., He, Q., Duncan, C. C., Hutchinson, D. T., Thumser, Z. C., Beckler, D. T., Marasco, P. D., Bensmaia, S. J., & Clark, G. A. (2019). Biomimetic sensory feedback through peripheral nerve stimulation improves dexterous use of a bionic hand. Science robotics, 4(32), eaax2352. https://doi.org/10.1126/scirobotics.aax2352

pageData.desc: A stylized illustration of many neurons.
pageData.altText: A stylized illustration of many neurons.

pageData.text: The nervous system is made up of the central nervous system and peripheral nervous system. These systems work together to collect and interpret data from the body’s internal and external environment and control responses.

pageData.altText: Human Body: Nervous System

pageData.subTitle: Central Nervous System
pageData.text: The central nervous system (CNS) manages the body’s essential functions. Made up of the brain and spinal cord, the CNS receives sensory information and coordinates an appropriate response.

pageData.subTitle: Peripheral Nervous System
pageData.text: The peripheral nervous system (PNS) connects the CNS to the rest of the body. Nerves branch out from the brain and spinal cord, extending to the organs, muscles, and other parts of the body.

Neurons are highly specialized cells that transmit chemical and electrical information in the body. Neurons use short, branched extensions called dendrites to receive nerve impulses from surrounding cells. These messages then travel through the cell body to the axon, a threadlike structure. The impulse moves through the axon and is transmitted via chemical or electrical signals that pass through a synapse.
Neurotransmitters are chemicals that relay signals between neurons and bodily tissues. Neurotransmitters include adrenaline, dopamine, and endorphins.

An organ system consists of a number of organs that operate collectively to carry out certain body functions. The body is made up of organ systems, each with specific tasks to perform to maintain life. Organ systems do not operate independently, but rather are coordinated for the organism to survive. The interdependence of organ systems needed for <button class='glossary-text'>homeostasis</button>—the dynamic equilibrium the body sustains when in good health—must be considered and understood.

At every level of organization—whether at the cellular, tissue, organ, or organ system level— each structure always reflects its function and vice versa. This concept is known as the . In this investigation, you will examine and dissect a mammalian brain to understand the structure of this important organ of the nervous system. The function of each component will be explained.
The nervous system is one of the two major control systems of the body; the other is the endocrine system. The nervous system has two major divisions:

text: The <button class='glossary-text'>central nervous system (CNS)</button>, consisting of the brain and <button class='glossary-text'>spinal cord</button>
The <button class='glossary-text'>peripheral nervous system (PNS)</button>, consisting of a network of <button class='glossary-text'>nerves</button> that extend throughout the body

pageData.text: The endocrine system is a collection of hormone-secreting glands, such as the pituitary, thyroid, and pancreas. The nervous system is capable of rapid, transient responses to stimuli. <button class='glossary-text'>Reflexes</button>, for example, are involuntary, practically instantaneous responses to stimuli. In contrast, the endocrine system generates slower, more sustained responses to stimuli. The two systems communicate with one another and, together, regulate the other organ systems of the body, coordinating their functions and maintaining homeostasis.

The organs of the nervous system are composed largely of nervous tissue. Two major cell types are present in nervous tissue: and . Neurons receive and transmit electrochemical signals called , while glia (also called glial cells or neuroglia) provide structural and metabolic support for the neurons. A typical neuron (see Figure 1) has three major components: the , , and the single .

text: The cell body (also called the soma) houses the nucleus and most of the organelles.
Dendrites convey impulses toward the cell body.
The single axon conveys impulses away from the cell body.

pageData.text: The long processes of neurons, typically axons, are often called <button class='glossary-text'>nerve fibers</button>.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Diagram of a typical neuron, showing multiple dendrites and a single axon with a myelin sheath extending from the cell body
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram of a typical neuron, showing multiple dendrites and a single axon with a myelin sheath extending from the cell body

pageData.question: Which of the following organ systems communicates with the nervous system to regulate other organ systems and maintain homeostasis?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The nervous system works together with the endocrine system to regulate other organ systems.

pageData.question: Which of the following are the two major cell types present in nervous tissue?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Neurons receive and transmit electrochemical signals called nerve impulses. Glia cells provide structural and metabolic support for neurons.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Communication between organ systems is essential for maintaining homeostasis. An example is the communication between the nervous and endocrine systems. For example, these systems work together to coordinate the release of hormones by the pituitary gland into the bloodstream to regulate body composition and body fluids. Communication between organ systems and the environment is also essential to maintaining homeostasis. The nervous system is capable of rapid, transient responses to external stimuli. For example, reflexes are involuntary, practically instantaneous responses to stimuli. There are two major cell types are present in nervous tissue: neurons and glia. Neurons receive and transmit electrochemical signals called nerve impulses, while glia (also called glial cells or neuroglia) provide structural and metabolic support for the neurons.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Communication between organ systems is essential for maintaining homeostasis. An example is the communication between the nervous and endocrine systems. For example, these systems work together to coordinate the release of hormones by the pituitary gland into the bloodstream to regulate body composition and body fluids. Communication between organ systems and the environment is also essential to maintaining homeostasis. The nervous system is capable of rapid, transient responses to external stimuli. For example, reflexes are involuntary, practically instantaneous responses to stimuli. There are two major cell types are present in nervous tissue: neurons and glia. Neurons receive and transmit electrochemical signals called nerve impulses, while glia (also called glial cells or neuroglia) provide structural and metabolic support for the neurons.

pageData.text: Communication occurs between a <button class='glossary-text'>neuron</button> and its target cell at a structure called a <button class='glossary-text'>synapse</button>. The target of a neuron may be another neuron, or an <button class='glossary-text'>effector</button>, which executes the response to the stimulus. Effectors may be muscle cells, which contract, or glandular cells, which secrete. Signaling molecules—called neurotransmitters—are released from the <button class='glossary-text'>axon terminal</button> (see <button class='resource-text'>Figure 1</button>) in response to a <button class='glossary-text'>nerve impulse</button>. They diffuse across the narrow space between the <button class='glossary-text'>axon</button> terminal and the surface of the target cell and bind to membrane-bound receptor molecules, bringing about changes in the target cell.

The incredible speed of interactions between neurons and their target cells becomes apparent when examining <button class='glossary-text'>reflexes</button>. Drawing the hand away from a hot surface or lifting the foot after stepping on a sharp object do not require voluntary action. These responses are automatic because they are reflex actions.

The cells involved in generating a reflex action make up a <button class='glossary-text'>reflex arc</button>. Reflex arcs can directly involve the brain or the <button class='glossary-text'>spinal cord</button>. <button class='resource-text'>Figure 2</button> depicts a spinal reflex arc. A stimulus is detected by a sensory receptor, which belongs to a sensory neuron. The sensory neuron sends a signal toward the spinal cord. The long process of the sensory neuron that carries the signal to the spinal cord is known as the <button class='glossary-text'>afferent fiber</button>. The sensory neuron synapses with the <button class='glossary-text'>cell body</button> or <button class='glossary-text'>dendrite</button> of an <button class='glossary-text'>interneuron</button> located in the spinal cord, which in turn stimulates a <button class='glossary-text'>motor neuron</button>. At the same time, the interneuron may pass the signal to other neurons that communicate with specific regions of the brain. The motor neuron responds to a strong stimulus by generating its own impulse, which passes down its axon, known as the <button class='glossary-text'>efferent fiber</button>, away from the spinal cord to a muscle cell.

There are many different <button class='glossary-text'>reflex arcs</button>, with variable numbers of <button class='glossary-text'>interneurons</button>. Simple <button class='glossary-text'>reflexes</button> lack interneurons altogether, while more complex reflex arcs may have more than one interneuron. Simple reflex arcs are the fastest, but when interneurons are present, they allow the brain to process and sometimes even inhibit the reflex. For example, if an object touches the eye, the blink reflex involuntarily closes the eyelid as a protective measure. However, the interneurons of the blink reflex arc make it possible to consciously keep the eyelid open even when an object (such as a contact lens) touches the surface of the eyeball.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Diagram of a spinal reflex arc showing the interactions between sensory receptor and sensory neuron, interneuron, motor nerve fiber, and muscle effector
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram of a spinal reflex arc showing the interactions between sensory receptor and sensory neuron, interneuron, motor nerve fiber, and muscle effector

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Gray matter</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>white matter</button> (see <button class='resource-text'>Figure 2</button>) are two distinct types of nervous tissue that appear quite different, both to the unassisted eye and under the microscope.

text: Gray matter is mainly made up of neuronal cell bodies and <button class='glossary-text'>dendrites</button>, with <button class='glossary-text'>axon terminals</button> and short <button class='glossary-text'>axons</button>, together with <button class='glossary-text'>glia</button> and tiny blood vessels. In preserved specimens, this type of nervous tissue appears gray.

White matter appears white because the axons that comprise it are sheathed in a fatty substance called <button class='glossary-text'>myelin</button>. This <button class='glossary-text'>myelin sheath</button> (see <button class='resource-text'>Figure 1</button>) is produced by certain glia—Schwann cells in the PNS and oligodendrocytes in the CNS. The myelin sheath facilitates the rapid transmission of <button class='glossary-text'>nerve</button> impulses along the axons. Myelinated axons have a shiny, white appearance.

pageData.text: In the CNS, gray matter tends to be superficially located in the brain, while occupying the interior of the . White matter of the CNS is associated with deeper regions of the brain and the region of the spinal cord. However, there are collections of gray matter known as deep within the brain. In the PNS, bundles of myelinated axons are termed nerves, and in the CNS, they are known as . Collections of gray matter belonging to the PNS are termed .

pageData.question: ______ is mainly made up of neuronal cell bodies and dendrites, with axon terminals and short axons, together with glia and tiny blood vessels.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Gray matter contains many neurons as well as glia and tiny blood vessels.

pageData.question: Why does white matter appear lighter than gray matter in preserved specimens?

options.text: White matter consists of myelinated neurons.
White matter is made up of a series of folds.
White matter is more delicate than gray matter.
White matter consists of more glia than gray matter.
The preservation process does not penetrate to the white matter.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: White matter consists of myelinated neurons while gray matter consists of unmyelinated neurons. Myelin has a shiny white appearance in preserved specimens.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In preserved specimens, this type of nervous tissue appears darker. While other tissues appear white because the axons that comprise it are sheathed in a fatty substance called myelin. This myelin sheath is produced by certain glia: Schwann cells in the PNS and oligodendrocytes in the CNS.

img.alt: A cross section of a preserved brain comprised mainly of light-colored tissue with a thin layer of darker superficial tissue.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In preserved specimens, this type of nervous tissue appears darker. While other tissues appear white because the axons that comprise it are sheathed in a fatty substance called myelin. This myelin sheath is produced by certain glia: Schwann cells in the PNS and oligodendrocytes in the CNS.

img.alt: A cross section of a preserved brain comprised mainly of light-colored tissue with a thin layer of darker superficial tissue.

pageData.text: The CNS is protected from injury by bones and fluid. The bones of the cranium and spine provide support and resistance to impact. Three connective tissue layers called (singular, meninx) surround the CNS (see Figure 3). The (also known simply as the dura) is the most of the meninges. It is separated from the only by a narrow, fluid-filled . The arachnoid is so named because it has a texture similar to that of a spiderweb. The deepest meninx is the , a delicate layer that adheres closely to the surface of the CNS. The CNS is essentially a hollow tube, having internal spaces filled with . This clear, colorless fluid is produced by specialized epithelium, the . CSF circulates through the of the ; through the four (expanded cavities) of the brain; and within the , which lies between the pia mater and the arachnoid. CSF is a vital part of CNS circulation and, especially within the subarachnoid space, helps to cushion the CNS and serve as a shock absorber.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Simplified drawing of the meninges and ventricles of the brain
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Simplified drawing of the meninges and ventricles of the brain

pageData.subTitle: Brain Structures and Their Functions
pageData.text: The brain is the most complex organ of the mammalian body. It has three major regions: the <button class='glossary-text'>hindbrain</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>midbrain</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>forebrain</button>. In addition, there is a region that coincides with the hindbrain and midbrain, known as the <button class='glossary-text'>brain stem</button>. As you read the descriptions below, locate the structures in bold type on the brain dissection mat.

text: The hindbrain includes two parts of the brain stem, which links the brain and <button class='glossary-text'>spinal cord</button>. These are the <button class='glossary-text'>medulla</button>—which is continuous with the spinal cord and regulates involuntary activities such as breathing, heartbeat, vomiting, coughing, and sneezing—and the bulb-shaped <button class='glossary-text'>pons</button>, an important relay center that helps regulate sleeping and breathing. The <button class='glossary-text'>cerebellum</button> is also part of the hindbrain. Cauliflower-like in appearance, it is of great importance in motor (movement) control. The <button class='glossary-text'>superficial</button>, cerebellar <button class='glossary-text'>cortex</button> consists of <button class='glossary-text'>gray matter</button>; the deeper, branching white matter is known as the <button class='glossary-text'>arbor vitae</button>.
The midbrain is the third part of the brain stem and serves to relay sensory and motor information between the spinal cord and the rest of the brain.

pageData.text: Four prominent bodies, known individually as a colliculus and collectively as the <button class='glossary-text'>corpora quadrigemina</button>, are located on the <button class='glossary-text'>superior</button> region of the midbrain. The two <button class='glossary-text'>superior colliculi</button> of the midbrain constitute an important visual <button class='glossary-text'>reflex</button> center—they help control the movement of the eyes, head, and neck in response to a stimulus such as a sudden loud noise or flash of light. The two <button class='glossary-text'>inferior colliculi</button> are associated with hearing.

The (see Figure 4) are a pair of cylindrical bodies comprising white matter that connects the cerebral with the and . Peduncle is derived from the Latin word for foot, and these structures do indeed resemble a pair of small feet located on either side of the .

text: The consists of the , , , and .The hypothalamus is of particular interest because it contains specialized hormonesecreting and is thus considered part of the endocrine system as well as the nervous system. The hypothalamus is crucial for regulating key processes that maintain .The thalamus is a very important relay center in the brain. All incoming sensory information, except for olfactory information, is relayed through the thalamus on its way to the cerebrum. Motor information from the and passes through the thalamus to the cerebral cortex. In addition, the thalamus helps to regulate sleep and consciousness.The pineal body is a tiny endocrine gland located just inferior to the thalamus. It is sensitive to light and secretes the hormone melatonin, which is important in the regulation of circadian rhythms (activities, such as sleeping and waking, that occur on an approximate 24-hour cycle) and the onset of sexual maturity.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Detailed drawing of an inferior view of a sheep's brain depicting the cranial nerves and adjacent stuctures
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Detailed drawing of an inferior view of a sheep's brain depicting the cranial nerves and adjacent stuctures

pageData.text: The is particularly prominent in mammals. Divided into right and left by a deep groove called the , the cerebrum organizes incoming sensory information; initiates voluntary motor activities; and is responsible for learning, memory, and judgment. The has a distinctive wrinkled appearance. The cerebral consists of , and the wrinkles increase the surface area of the cortex. The crests of the wrinkles are called (singular, gyrus) and the shallow grooves are (singular, sulcus). White matter lie deep to the cerebral cortex. The most prominent of these is the that connects the cerebral hemispheres. Embedded in the white matter of the cerebrum are collections of gray matter known as the (formerly basal ). The basal nuclei play important roles in voluntary movements, habitual movements, and learning.

The cerebral cortex can be structurally and functionally divided into regions referred to as lobes. The <button class='glossary-text'>frontal lobe</button> is responsible for cognitive processes such as planning, reasoning, judgement, and the control of emotional and sexual drives. The <button class='glossary-text'>parietal lobe</button> integrates sensory information (for example, from receptors in the skin) and functions in spatial perception (i.e., the ability to assess the shape, size, orientation, and motion of objects). The <button class='glossary-text'>temporal lobe</button> functions in auditory perception (including language) and long-term memory. The <button class='glossary-text'>occipital lobe</button> receives and processes visual information. The <button class='glossary-text'>pyriform lobe</button> (see <button class='resource-text'>Figure 4</button>) receives and processes olfactory information. It is very prominent in some mammals, such as sheep, but relatively small in humans.

pageData.subTitle: Ventricles
pageData.text: The brain contains four interconnected, CSF filled (see ). The are located in the cerebrum, separated by the . The is located between the right and left halves of the and is connected to the lateral ventricles by the foramen of Monro (interventricular foramen). The is located between the and the . CSF flows between the ventricles and the of the .

pageData.question: Which of the following processes does the medulla regulate?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The medulla is part of the hindbrain and regulates involuntary activities like breathing, heartbeat, coughing, sneezing and vomiting.

pageData.question: Which of the following processes is NOT regulated by the brain stem?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The cerebellum, which regulates motor control, is part of the hindbrain but not part of the brain stem.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The brain is the most complex organ of the mammalian body. It has three major regions: the hindbrain, midbrain, and forebrain. The hindbrain includes two parts of the brain stem, which links the brain and spinal cord. These are the medulla, which is continuous with the spinal cord and regulates involuntary activities such as breathing, heartbeat, vomiting, coughing, and sneezing; and the bulb-shaped pons, an important relay center that helps regulate sleeping and breathing. The cerebellum is also part of the hindbrain. Cauliflower-like in appearance, it is of great importance in motor (movement) control.

img.alt: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the medulla, pons, and cerebellum labeled.

The hindbrain includes two parts of the brain stem, which links the brain and spinal cord. These are the medulla, which is continuous with the spinal cord and regulates involuntary activities such as breathing, heartbeat, vomiting, coughing, and sneezing; and the bulb-shaped pons, an important relay center that helps regulate sleeping and breathing. The cerebellum is also part of the hindbrain. Cauliflower-like in appearance, it is of great importance in motor (movement) control.

pageData.subTitle: Cranial Nerves and Their Functions
pageData.text: When the brain is viewed from its aspect, you can observe 12 pairs of (see and ) emerging from the brain and . These conduct information flowing between the brain and nearby areas of the body. conveying information toward the brain are often described as and those conveying information away from the brain as . Three of the cranial nerves conduct only incoming sensory information to the brain, five carry only motor commands originating in the brain, and four are known as mixed because they are composed of a combination of sensory and motor nerve fibers. Each pair of cranial nerves may be designated by a Roman numeral or by name. Although all the cranial nerves are paired, they are conventionally referred to in the singular.

tableData.text: Gustation, oral, and pharyngeal sensation; salivation; swallowing; and blood pressure

pageData.question: When the brain is viewed from its inferior aspect, you can observe 12 pairs of cranial nerves emerging from which of the following structures?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Cranial nerves emerge from the brain and brain stem and conduct information flowing between the brain and nearby areas of the body.

pageData.question: Some cranial nerves conduct only one of two types of information either to or from the brain, while other nerves conduct both types of information. Which of the following describes these two types of information?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Cranial nerves conduct either sensory information to the brain, motor information from the brain, or both.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Cranial nerves relay information between the brain and parts of the body, primarily to and from regions of the head and neck. Nerve fibers conveying information toward the brain are often described as afferent fibers and those conveying information away from the brain as efferent fibers. Three of the cranial nerves conduct only incoming sensory information to the brain, five carry only motor commands originating in the brain, and four are known as mixed nerves because they are composed of a combination of sensory and motor nerve fibers.

img.alt: Figure 4: Detailed drawing of an inferior view of a sheep's brain depicting the cranial nerves and adjacent stuctures.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Cranial nerves relay information between the brain and parts of the body, primarily to and from regions of the head and neck. Nerve fibers conveying information toward the brain are often described as afferent fibers and those conveying information away from the brain as efferent fibers. Three of the cranial nerves conduct only incoming sensory information to the brain, five carry only motor commands originating in the brain, and four are known as mixed nerves because they are composed of a combination of sensory and motor nerve fibers.

img.alt: Figure 4: Detailed drawing of an inferior view of a sheep's brain depicting the cranial nerves and adjacent stuctures.

text: The <button class='glossary-text'>olfactory nerve (I)</button> arises from olfactory receptor <button class='glossary-text'>neurons</button> in the olfactory epithelium of the nasal cavity. Their <button class='glossary-text'>afferent fibers</button> pass through the bony roof of the nasal cavity to one of the <button class='glossary-text'>olfactory bulbs</button>, making the olfactory nerve the shortest of all the <button class='glossary-text'>cranial nerves</button>. For this reason, the olfactory nerve is not shown in <button class='resource-text'>Figure 4</button>. However, the olfactory bulbs are depicted. The paired olfactory bulbs lie underneath the <button class='glossary-text'>anterior</button> portion of the <button class='glossary-text'>cerebrum</button> and are connected to target regions of the brain via the <button class='glossary-text'>olfactory tract</button>. Unlike most sensory input, olfactory information is not relayed through the <button class='glossary-text'>thalamus</button>; rather, it passes to a number of brain areas, including those devoted to memory and emotion as well as sensory perception.

The retinas of the eyes are mainly composed of nervous tissue and are considered part of the brain. Retinal neurons give rise to the <button class='glossary-text'>optic nerve (II)</button> and originate in each eye. The pair of <button class='glossary-text'>optic nerves</button> come together to form an x-shaped structure, the <button class='glossary-text'>optic chiasm</button> (or optic chiasma), located near the base of the brain near the <button class='glossary-text'>hypothalamus</button>. This is where many <button class='glossary-text'>nerve fibers</button> decussate, or crisscross, before continuing via the <button class='glossary-text'>optic tract</button> to the thalamus. Decussation of nerve fibers carrying visual information is essential for binocular vision, i.e., the formation of a single, continuous image using input from both eyes.

The <button class='glossary-text'>oculomotor nerve (III)</button> arises from the <button class='glossary-text'>midbrain</button>. It has efferent connections to most of the extraocular muscles, which move the eyes and eyelids, and to the sphincter muscle of the iris, which controls pupil diameter. Damage to the third cranial nerve may result in the so-called down-and-out signs: the affected eye gazes downward and laterally instead of straight ahead.

The <button class='glossary-text'>trochlear nerve (IV)</button> arises from the <button class='glossary-text'>brain stem</button>. Unlike the other cranial nerves, it emerges from the <button class='glossary-text'>superior</button> aspect of the brain. It consists of a small number of efferent nerve fibers that supply a specific extraocular muscle (the superior oblique), which helps rotate the eyeball in its socket.

The <button class='glossary-text'>trigeminal nerve (V)</button> is named for its three distinct branches: the ophthalmic nerve, the maxillary nerve, and the mandibular nerve. These branches converge on the trigeminal ganglion, from which afferent fibers run together to the <button class='glossary-text'>pons</button> to provide sensory input from the face. <button class='glossary-text'>Efferent fibers</button> also originate in the pons to supply motor input to muscles responsible for mastication (chewing).

The <button class='glossary-text'>abducens nerve (VI)</button> emerges from the brain at the level of the <button class='glossary-text'>pons</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>medulla</button>, just <button class='glossary-text'>posterior</button> to the <button class='glossary-text'>trigeminal nerve</button>. It consists of efferent motor fibers that supply an extraocular muscle (the <button class='glossary-text'>lateral</button> rectus) responsible for abduction of the eye. In other words, it rotates the eye so that the pupil moves away from the body’s <button class='glossary-text'>midline</button>.

Like the abducens nerve, the <button class='glossary-text'>facial nerve (VII)</button> emerges between the pons and medulla. Its <button class='glossary-text'>efferent fibers</button> stimulate the muscles responsible for facial expression, and its <button class='glossary-text'>afferent fibers</button> convey sensory information pertaining to taste. A common form of temporary facial paralysis known as Bell’s palsy occurs as the result of inflammation of the facial nerve.

The <button class='glossary-text'>vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII)</button> carries sensory information about balance and hearing from the inner ear. The afferent sensory fibers of this nerve enter the brain in the region between the pons and medulla.

The <button class='glossary-text'>glossopharyngeal nerve (IX)</button> is a mixednerve that emerges laterally from the medulla. Its efferent motor fibers supply a muscle (the stylopharyngeus) that plays an important role in swallowing and speech, and the large parotid salivary gland. The afferent fibers of <button class='glossary-text'>cranial nerve</button> IX convey information about sensations of the throat, ear, and tongue; the sense of gustation; and blood pressure.

The <button class='glossary-text'>vagus nerve (X)</button> is a mixed <button class='glossary-text'>nerve</button> that emerges from the medulla and sends afferent fibers to the intestines and heart as well as conveys efferent input about gustation and visceral sensation to the brain.

The <button class='glossary-text'>spinal accessory nerve (XI)</button> is a motor <button class='glossary-text'>nerve</button> that supplies information to the head and the trapezius muscle, which elevates the shoulder and adducts the forelimb (moves the forelimb toward the <button class='glossary-text'>midline</button> of the body). The <button class='glossary-text'>motor neurons</button>, whose fibers make up the spinal accessory nerve, are located in the upper portion of the <button class='glossary-text'>spinal cord</button>.

The is a motor nerve that supplies information to the tongue. Its emerge from the and form a nerve that runs under the tongue. In fact, the name of this nerve translates as under (hypo) the tongue (glossus). Tongue movements involved in chewing, swallowing, and speech are controlled by information passing down this nerve.

pageData.text: Anatomists and health-care providers use specific terminology to ensure precise communication. Directional anatomical terms describe the relative positions of body structures or provide instructions for incisions. Directional anatomical terms (see Figure 5 and <button class='glossary-text'>Glossary Tab</button>) are used in this and most other dissection guides. Therefore, learning these terms is essential for the understanding and study of anatomy

Note: All mammalian brains are similar in structure and function. However, there is one distinct difference between the and of a biped, such as a human, and those of a quadruped, such as a sheep. A biped is a vertical animal that walks on two legs; thus, the spinal cord and brain stem are perpendicular to the ground. The spinal cord and brain stem of a quadruped are parallel to the ground. As a result, certain directional terms can vary between quadrupeds and bipeds. This variation can be especially challenging when studying a single organ removed from the context of the entire body, as in this brain dissection.Since this investigation is commonly used in human anatomy and physiology courses, human (biped) terminology is used for indicating directions (see the human brain labeled in ). Quadruped terminology is included in as reference for those enrolled in a comparative or veterinary anatomy course.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Lateral view of a human brain with directional terms
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Lateral view of a human brain with directional terms

text: Paper towels
70% isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) or other non-bleach disinfectant
Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking photos
Opaque trash bag

pageData.text:
Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for the Anatomy of the Brain investigation (item number 580522) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company.
  • Carosafe® sheep brain (item number 228711)
  • Dissection Set (item number 580021)
Call: 866-332-4478 to order.
This investigation requires safety goggles, disposable gloves, and a lab apron.

pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Follow the instructions for this activity closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including using appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE). Safety goggles, gloves, and lab aprons must be worn when dissecting. Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing the dissection. Use proper hygiene practices before, during, and after the lab, including washing your hands before and after performing the dissection. Review pertinent portions of any Safety Data Sheets before beginning the activity.Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
Dissections require special attention to safety. Please follow these additional precautions:

text: Clean the counter or work space thoroughly before and after the dissection, using isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant).

pageData.text: Isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) is flammable. Keep away from open flame if using alcohol as a disinfectant.
pageData.altText: flammable symbol

text: Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water before and after the dissection.
Only perform the dissection on the dissecting tray. This will contain both the specimen and any excess fluids.
Spread the absorbent pad blue-side down underneath the tray to capture any spilled fluid.
In general, scissors are used more frequently than the scalpel, especially when care must be taken not to cut too deep into the specimen.

Scalpels are used infrequently in most dissection labs and require special handling and disposal:
  • Never cut toward your holding hand and fingers.
  • Cut in a downward motion using a steady, even pressure.
  • Always use a sharp blade.
  • Do not use a scalpel that is nicked, bent, or damaged.
  • Do not use a scalpel to cut through bone or heavy cartilage.
  • Never use a scalpel for anything other than dissection.

pageData.subTitle: Carolina’s Carosafe<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>
pageData.text: Carosafe® is a preservative and holding solution for biological specimens. It contains no formaldehyde and is not a tissue fixative. Most specimens in Carosafe® are first preserved with a formalin solution and then washed and placed in formaldehyde-free Carosafe®. This produces a formalin-preserved specimen that, when dissected, minimizes exposure to formaldehyde.

The primary component of Carosafe<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> is propylene glycol, a common ingredient used in cosmetics and foods. Propylene glycol is on the U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s list of food additives that are generally recognized as safe. Holding specimens in Carosafe<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>reduces the presence of formaldehyde, thereby diminishing or eliminating unpleasant odor. However, Carosafe<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>-preserved specimens and their surrounding fluid do contain some residual formaldehyde, a by-product of the initial formalin preservation process. The amount present varies by specimen type.

The dissection should take place in a well-ventilated setting. For a home setting, this may include opening windows and turning on a ceiling fan. The safe nature of Carosafe<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>also means that in most localities there are no mandated disposal requirements.

Carosafe<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> causes mild skin irritation if suitable PPE is not worn. Avoid contact with skin and eyes. Carosafe<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>is harmful if swallowed. Do not ingest the specimen, especially if you are or may become pregnant.
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.subTitle: Storage of Specimens
pageData.text: If it is necessary to store the specimen between work periods, you may choose to place it in the self-locking storage bag with as much of the original solution as possible. Establishing an airtight seal is the best way to retain specimen integrity and prevent drying out of the specimen. First, squeeze as much air out of the specimen bag as possible before securing the seal with tape or a binder clip. After sealing the bag, the specimen can be stored in a larger, airtight box or bag at room temperature.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Gray matter and white matter in the brain differ in their structure and function. Which of the following best describes these differences?

options.text: White matter has myelinated neurons and rapidly transmits nerve impulses.
Gray matter has enlarged cell bodies and supports the brain with nutrients.
White matter is made up of glia and secretes hormones.
Gray matter is made of epithelial tissue and produces cerebrospinal fluid.
Gray matter is only found in the brain stem and facilitates involuntary processes.

assestmentData.pageTitle: Drag and Drop Knowledge Check Question
assestmentData.question: Match each brain structure with its function.

options.text: relay center for all non-olfactory sensory information
connects the left and right cerebral hemispheres

assestmentData.question: In this investigation, the meninges of the preserved mammalian brain provided in your lab kit are intact. Which of the following lists the meninges in order from outermost to innermost?

assestmentData.pageTitle: Drag and Drop Knowledge Check Question
assestmentData.question: Match each cranial nerve with its function.
Which of the following best describes the difference between the roles of afferent and efferent fibers in a reflex arc?

options.text: Afferent fibers convey sensory impulses; efferent fibers signal muscles and glands.
Afferent fibers convey sensory impulses; efferent fibers inhibit sensory impulses.
Afferent fibers signal muscles and glands; efferent fibers convey sensory impulses.
Afferent fibers convey impulses to muscles; efferent fibers convey impulses to glands.
Afferent fibers terminate the reflex arc; efferent fibers initiate the reflex arc.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following are responsible for producing myelin for certain types of neurons?
Which of the following is a safety concern of the preservation fluid used to preserve the mammalian brain provided for this investigation?

options.text: It can cause mild skin irritation if proper PPE is not worn.
It gives off toxic fumes and requires specialized ventilation techniques.
It is corrosive and must be stored in its original container.
It cannot be disposed of in the household trash.
If you are or may become pregnant, do not open the specimen.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following scenarios describes inappropriate handling of a scalpel?

options.text: Christina places her holding hand inferior to the movement of her scalpel.
Odette disposes of her scalpel after noticing the blade is bent.
Jasmine uses consistent pressure as she makes a small incision.
Teresa makes an incision by moving the scalpel down toward the tray.
Linda trades the scalpel for scissors when she encounters thick cartilage mid-incision.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following structures of the cerebrum is involved with cognitive processes, such as planning and the inhibition of drives?
Which of the following structures of the brain are considered part of both the nervous and endocrine systems?

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Review the dissection instructions and the glossary at the end of this investigation.
Print out the dissection procedure and to avoid getting fluid from the specimen on your computer or mobile device.
Clean the work area. Put on your PPE—safety goggles, gloves, and lab apron—and keep them on during the dissection and cleanup.
Lay the pad on the work area with the white, absorbent side facing up.
Lay the scalpel, forceps, scissors, and probe from the dissecting set on the pad.
Inspect the scalpel. Do not use the scalpel if it is bent, nicked, or damaged.
Place the dissecting tray in the middle of the pad to absorb any fluid that might spill onto the work area.
Position the dissection mat so you can view it easily.

In Activity 1, you will examine the <button class='glossary-text'>meninges</button> of the intact preserved brain. After removing the meninges, you will locate and identify additional external structures. Then, you will divide the specimen into equal left and right halves and examine the internal structures.

pages.title: Examination of the Intact Brain (4 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Examination of the Intact Brain (4 steps)

typeBefore.text: Note: Camera icons and instructions in this activity are intended as prompts for documenting your work. For best practices in specimen photography, view the following video:
Please follow any additional directions provided by your instructor pertaining to the photography and/or identification of specific structures.

pageData.text: Examine the , the white layer of connective tissue enveloping the brain. Pull on it gently with your forceps to examine its tough texture. Gently remove the dura by separating it from underlying structures with the wooden probe, taking care to leave all (as shown in ) intact. You may notice some weblike material clinging to the surface of the brain. This is .For additional guidance on the dissection procedure, view the video:

pageData.subTitle: How to Dissect a Mammalian Brain

pageData.desc: How to Dissect a Mammalian Brain

pageData.text: Take a photo of a <button class='glossary-text'>superior</button> view of the brain. Then begin studying the external features of the intact mammalian brain, using the dissection mat as a guide. The numbers in parentheses correspond to numbered structures on the mat.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

text: The most prominent features are the right and left <button class='glossary-text'>hemispheres</button> of the <button class='glossary-text'>cerebrum</button> (1). Note the <button class='glossary-text'>sulci</button> (19) and <button class='glossary-text'>gyri</button> (20) of the cerebral <button class='glossary-text'>cortex</button>. The two cerebral hemispheres are separated from one another by the <button class='glossary-text'>medial</button> longitudinal fissure (9).
Identify the lobes of the cerebrum: frontal (4), parietal (5), temporal (6), and occipital (7).
<button class='glossary-text'>Posterior</button> to the cerebrum, observe the smaller <button class='glossary-text'>cerebellum</button> (2).

pageData.text: Position the brain inferior-side up, and take a photo. For orientation, locate the cerebrum (1) and cerebellum (2). In addition to the dissection mat, refer to <button class='resource-text'>Figure 4</button>, which depicts all the <button class='glossary-text'>cranial</button> nerves as well as other inferiorly visible structures not indicated on the mat.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

text: Locate the large, anteriorly situated pair of <button class='glossary-text'>olfactory bulbs</button> (17). These receive input from each <button class='glossary-text'>olfactory nerve</button> (I). Note their relationship to the <button class='glossary-text'>pyriform lobe</button>, which receives and processes olfactory information.

Looking from an <button class='glossary-text'>anterior</button> to posterior direction, locate the <button class='glossary-text'>optic nerves</button> (II, 16), <button class='glossary-text'>optic chiasm</button> (15), and <button class='glossary-text'>optic tracts</button> (14). (Note that only stumps of the optic nerves will be present.)

Find the <button class='glossary-text'>hypothalamus</button> (32), located just posterior to the optic chiasm (15) and anterior to the <button class='glossary-text'>brain stem</button> (11). (Although the pituitary is usually detached from the <button class='glossary-text'>inferior</button> portion of the hypothalamus when the brain is removed from the cranial cavity, occasionally this small gland or a fragment of it will remain. If so, gently remove the pituitary and set it aside.)

Locate the brain stem (11). The <button class='glossary-text'>medulla</button> (12) is the portion of the brain stem that is continuous with the <button class='glossary-text'>spinal cord</button> (3). The <button class='glossary-text'>pons</button> (13) is located between the medulla (12) and the <button class='glossary-text'>midbrain</button> (18), which is the most <button class='glossary-text'>superior</button> region of the brain stem. Note the <button class='glossary-text'>pyramidal tracts</button> of the medulla and the <button class='glossary-text'>cerebral peduncles</button> of the midbrain.  Together, these structures link the cerebral cortex with the brain stem and spinal cord.

Observe the oculomotor (III) and trochlear (IV) nerves. The <button class='glossary-text'>oculomotor nerves</button> should be visible as they emerge from the posterior region of the midbrain. The <button class='glossary-text'>trochlear nerves</button> (IV) are very small and emerge from the junction of the midbrain and the pons.

Identify the <button class='glossary-text'>trigeminal nerves</button> (V), <button class='glossary-text'>abducens nerves</button> (VI), and <button class='glossary-text'>facial nerves</button> (VII), all of which emerge from the pons (13).
Locate the junction of the pons (13) and medulla (12). Here, you should see the emergence of the <button class='glossary-text'>vestibulocochlear nerve</button> (VIII).
Examine the medulla from anterior to posterior, noting the locations of the glossopharyngeal (IX), vagus (X), spinal accessory (XI), and hypoglossal (XII) nerves.

pageData.text: Position the brain superior-side up, and gently spread the cerebrum and cerebellum apart, so that the midbrain is exposed. Refer to <button class='resource-text'>Figure 6</button>.

text: Locate the <button class='glossary-text'>corpora quadrigemina</button>—the four mound-shaped structures projecting from the <button class='glossary-text'>superior</button> surface of the midbrain. The larger pair are the <button class='glossary-text'>superior colliculi</button>, and the smaller ones are the <button class='glossary-text'>inferior colliculi</button>.
Anterior to the superior colliculi, note the <button class='glossary-text'>pineal body</button>.

pageData.desc: Figure 6: Brain folded to expose the structures of the midbrain
pageData.altText: Figure 6: Brain folded to expose the structures of the midbrain

typeBefore.title:
B
 Examination of the Longitudinally Sectioned Brain (2 steps)

pageData.text: Position the brain superior-side up, and use the scalpel to cut the entire brain longitudinally along the <button class='glossary-text'>medial longitudinal fissure</button> (9). The incision will separate the brain into equal right and left halves, as shown on the back of the dissection mat.
Take a photo of a medial view of one or both hemispheres (8, 10). Then use the dissection mat as a guide as you locate and identify the following structures:
pageData.altText: camera symbol

text: The <button class='glossary-text'>corpus callosum</button> (31) is the <button class='glossary-text'>tract</button> that links the right and left cerebral hemispheres (8, 10). Along with the <button class='glossary-text'>septum pellucidum</button> (21), it comprises the boundaries of the <button class='glossary-text'>right and left lateral ventricles</button> (23).
The <button class='glossary-text'>thalamus</button> (30) lies inferior to the corpus callosum (31); the <button class='glossary-text'>third ventricle</button> (22) lies between its two halves.
The hypothalamus (32) is inferior to the thalamus.

The <button class='glossary-text'>arbor vitae</button> (25) is the white matter network within the cerebellum (2). Note that the outer layer of the cerebellum consists of <button class='glossary-text'>gray matter</button>.
The <button class='glossary-text'>fourth ventricle</button> (24) lies between the cerebellum (2) and the brain stem (11).

From anterior to posterior, the brain stem (11) consists of the midbrain (18) with the corpora quadrigemina, including the superior colliculi (26); pons (13); and medulla (12). Recall that the medulla is continuous with the spinal cord (3).
The pineal body (29) lies between the thalamus (30) and the superior colliculi (26).
Dispose of any excess fluids down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run for about 30 seconds to dilute the fluids.
Place the specimen in its storage bag and seal tightly. If you are finished working with your specimen, put the bag into an opaque trash bag for disposal in the household garbage.
Rinse and carefully air-dry the dissection tools, and return the materials to your equipment kit.
Sanitize the work space with isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant) and paper towels.
If this is insufficient for removing grease during cleanup, use soap and water, followed by more alcohol/disinfectant.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.altText: completion

pageData.text:

  • Cerebellum
    • Arbor vitae
  • Corpus callosum
  • Brain stem
    • Midbrain
      • Superior colliculus
    • Pons
    • Medulla
  • Thalamus
  • Hypothalamus

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation.
You will start by setting up the work area and the dissection tools.
In Activity 1, you will examine the dura mater of the intact specimen. Then, you will remove the dura mater of the intact specimen. Next, locate and identify the external structures of the intact specimen.
In Activity 2, you will divide the specimen longitudinally. Then, locate and identify the internal structures of the specimen.

pageData.content: How to Dissect a Mammalian Brain
Figure 6. The exposed midbrain of a preserved brain
pageData.altText: Figure 6: Brain folded to expose the structures of the midbrain

data.title: Abducens nerve
data.content: Emerges from the brain at the level of the pons and medulla, just posterior to the trigeminal nerve, rotates the eye so that the pupil moves away from the body’s midline

data.title: Axon
data.content: Conveys impulses away from the cell body

data.title: Axon terminal
data.content: Small swellings that are found at the terminal ends of axons

data.title: Brain nuclei
data.content: Collections of grey matter neurons in the cerebrum and brainstem

data.title: Cell body
data.content: Houses the nucleus and most of the organelles (soma)

data.title: Central canal
data.content: In compact bone, blood vessels and nerves that serve the bone cells

data.title: Central nervous system (CNS)
data.content: Complex of nerve tissues that controls the activities of the body, in vertebrates it comprises the brain and spinal cord

data.title: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
data.content: Clear, colorless fluid that fills the CNS

data.title: Choroid plexus
data.content: Specialized epithelium that produces the CSF

data.title: Dendrite
data.content: Convey impulses toward the cell body

data.title: Effector
data.content: Part of a nerve that executes the response to the stimulus

data.title: Facial nerve
data.content: Emerges between the pons and medulla, Its efferent fibers stimulate the muscles responsible for facial expression, and its afferent fibers convey sensory information pertaining to taste

data.title: Fourth ventricle
data.content: Located between the cerebellum and the brain stem

data.title: Ganglia
data.content: Masses of nerves

data.title: Glia
data.content: Provide support for the neurons (called glial cells or neuroglia)

data.title: Glossopharyngeal nerve
data.content: A mixed nerve that emerges laterally from the medulla, plays an important role in swallowing and speech, and the large parotid salivary gland

data.title: Gray matter
data.content: The darker tissue of the brain and spinal cord, consisting mainly of made up mainly of neuronal cell bodies; dendrites; and short, unmyelinated axons, together with glia and tiny blood vessels

data.title: Homeostasis
data.content: Is a self-regulating process by which biological systems maintain stability while adjusting to environmental changes

data.title: Hypoglossal nerve
data.content: A motor nerve that supplies information to the tongue

data.title: Interneurons (association neurons)
data.content: Located between sensory and motor neuron, the most abundant type of neuron

data.title: Motor neuron (efferent neuron)
data.content: Generate impulses that simulate muscle cells to contract, send impulses away from the CNS

data.title: Myelin sheath
data.content: An insulating layer that forms around nerves

data.title: Nerve
data.content: Bundle of myelinated axons that transmits impulses of sensation to the brain or spinal cord, and impulses from these to the muscles and organs

data.title: Nerve fiber
data.content: Long processes of neurons, typically axons

data.title: Nerve impulse
data.content: Electrochemical signal

data.title: Neuron
data.content: Receive and transmit electrochemical signals (nerve impulses)

data.title: Oculomotor nerve
data.content: Arises from the midbrain, has efferent connections to most of the extraocular muscles, which move the eyes and eyelids, and to the sphincter muscle of the iris, which controls pupil diameter

data.title: Olfactory nerve
data.content: Arises from olfactory receptor neurons in the olfactory epithelium of the nasal cavity

data.title: Peripheral nervous system (PNS)
data.content: Consisting of a network of nerves that extend throughout the body

data.title: Principle of complementarity of structure and function
data.content: Principle of complementarity of structure and function, each anatomical structure always reflects its function and vice versa

data.title: Reflex
data.content: Involuntary, practically instantaneous responses to stimuli

data.title: Reflex arc
data.content: The cells involved in generating a reflex reaction

data.title: Right and left lateral ventricles
data.content: Located in the cerebrum, separated by the septum pellucidum

data.title: Spinal accessory nerve
data.content: A motor nerve that supplies information to the head and the trapezius muscle, which elevates the shoulder and adducts the forelimb

data.title: Subarachnoid space
data.content: Lies between the pia mater and the arachnoid

data.title: Subdural space (subdural cavity)
data.content: Space that can be opened by the separation of the arachnoid mater from the dura mater

data.title: Superficial cerebral cortex
data.content: The outermost layer of the brain,  has a distinctive wrinkled appearance

data.title: Synapse
data.content: The site of transmission of electric nerve impulses between two neurons

data.title: Third ventricle
data.content: Located between the right and left halves of the thalamus and is connected to the lateral ventricles by the foramen of Monro

data.title: Tract
data.content: A bundle of fibers in the nervous system, mostly white matter

data.title: Trigeminal nerve
data.content: Named for its three distinct branches: the ophthalmic nerve, the maxillary nerve, and the mandibular nerve

data.title: Trochlear nerve
data.content: Arises from the brain stem, emerges from the superior aspect of the brain, consists of a small number of efferent nerve fibers that supply a specific extraocular muscle (the superior oblique), which helps rotate the eyeball in its socket

data.title: Vagus nerve
data.content: A mixed nerve that emerges from the medulla and sends afferent fibers to the intestines and heart as well as conveys efferent input about gustation and visceral sensation to the brain

data.title: Vestibulocochlear nerve
data.content: Carries sensory information about balance and hearing from the inner ear
